body:
@lustoykov this piece of code was actually in `componentDidMount()` as shown [in this example.](https://github.com/mauron85/react-native-background-geolocation/#quick-example)

But I changed it to a local function instead. It works, but is it okay to do so? I'm a little confused.

Do you still need this code? 

In general, you try to get rid of code in comments, because soon nobody remembers, whether it is safe to delete the code or remove the comment. ;)

Personal taste coming 😅 

I don't like shortcuts in class names, methods or variables. When you use a reasonable IDE, there should be autocompletion during typing, therefore it takes you no longer to type the stuff.
Moreover, readability of your code would increase a lot, when you write out BackgroundTracker. 

Btw. I first thought it is BugTracker :D
This is inproper usage of React, you never modify directly props, but rather setState where the props come from & let the changes propagate down. Never mutate directly state or props

Should
```
geoStates : {
                lon : [],
                lat : [],
                timestamp : []
            }
``` 
be declared inside the state in the file it came from (`BackgroundTracker.js`), and a function should setState it there, and the actual values should be passed to `BackgroundTracker.js` from  this file `StartStopButton.js`?

EDIT : got it.

Why don't you get this from the length of the list in the trip field? 

If you do it like that, you have to guarantee atomic updates. ;)
Is there no Date library in JS? 🤔
We are now going to remove the `User` part of the database since we don't have a login. We will just record trips.

You don't have to change it here for the prototype. 
But in general, you should try to avoid having passwords hard coded in the code. ;)
It might be helpful for debugging if you at least log the error.
